headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. With me today are Abhi Talwalkar, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Bryon Look, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Abhi will begin the call with some opening remarks and highlights
componenttext:
Good afternoon, and thank you for joining us. With me today are Abhi Talwalkar, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Bryon Look, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Abhi will begin the call with some opening remarks and highlights from our business, and then Bryon will provide results and guidance for the second quarter of 2010.
During this call, we'll be mentioning non-GAAP financial measures, which we may refer to as results excluding special items. Today's earnings release describes the differences between our non-GAAP and GAAP reporting. You can find reconciliations of our non-GAAP financial measures to corresponding GAAP amounts on our website at www.lsi.com/webcast. At that site, you can also find copies of the earnings release and a presentation, which highlights the key points from today's call and provides an overview of our business. This may be particularly useful to investors who are new to LSI.
I want to remind you that today's remarks will include forward-looking statements. Our actual results could differ materially from those suggested by the statements made today. Information about factors that could affect our future results is contained in our annual report on Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2009. With that, it is now my pleasure to introduce Abhi Talwalkar.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Sujal. Good afternoon, and welcome. I'm continued to be pleased with our execution and the progress we're making across our businesses. Just last month, we held an event with analysts and investors where we talked about successful transformatio
componenttext:
Thank you, Sujal. Good afternoon, and welcome. I'm continued to be pleased with our execution and the progress we're making across our businesses. Just last month, we held an event with analysts and investors where we talked about successful transformation of LSI and the strong opportunities we have for growth as we move forward. We appreciate all of the positive feedback we received from analysts, existing holders and potential new shareholders following this event. I will reinforce some of those highlights today and also provide further updates in each of our businesses.
For Q1, revenues were at the high end of the upwardly revised guidance range that we provided in mid-March. We grew 9%, sequentially, in our Semiconductor business driven by increases in networking standard and custom products, SAN and IP licensing. We also had revenue significantly above typical seasonality in our Storage Systems, HDD and SAS businesses, reflecting improving end demand. Our first quarter non-GAAP operating margins were 11.7%. LSI generated double-digit operating margins in the first quarter of the calendar year, which is typically our weakest seasonal quarter, demonstrating the operating leverage we have created through the transformation of the company.
During the quarter, we also repurchased $26 million worth of stock under our $250 million share repurchase authorization. 
Before I talk about our businesses, here are the key takeaways that I would like you to get from this call: First, we continue to secure significant design wins with industry leaders across our businesses. Second, we are positioned to grow faster than the markets we serve. And third, we are executing to our business and financial milestones and are focused on delivering solid progress against our business model this year.
At our Analyst Day event last month, we showed the transformation that has occurred at LSI over the past several years. This included focusing on fewer and larger end markets, going after established and growing applications and narrowing our focus to market-leading customers.
This focus, combined with product leadership, has resulted in a design win pipeline that is unprecedented in value and robustness for LSI. Our annual design win values over the past few years in our Semi segment have been in the range of 1.5x to 2x higher than our reported annual revenues in that segment. Additionally, in our Networking business, our strategy is resulting in an improved design win conversion rate, which is the percentage of design win value that we expect to reach production and materialize into revenue. All of this gives us great confidence in the future of revenue growth.
I'm very pleased that we are successfully executing on design win milestones we outlined. Last year, we had told the investment community that we would expand our customer base in HDD and growing SAS. Last month, we indicated that we had one SoC across all five HDD OEMs and that two of the top three server OEMs chose LSI SAS ROC and server RAID solutions for their 2011 Intel Romley server generation. We also successfully intercepted the solid state drive market at the right time and continue to win with market leaders in networking, where we announced our first major Axxia network processor win at one of the top two wireless infrastructure players. We are also solidly positioned in markets that have strong growth projections and low volatility. 
Overall, we believe our end markets have recovered considerably from the economic downturn, and supply and demand continue to be in balance. While the supply chain has been tight, we have managed to meet customer demand requirements. In fact, for Q1, we believe that LSI's performance was in line or better than our served markets. Our external storage and ACD businesses performed roughly in line with IDC's estimates of end market performance for the first quarter. We believe that we outgrew the market in our Server and Storage Connectivity businesses and in networking standard and custom products for Q1. 
Now I want to review with you the business highlights for last quarter in our Storage and Networking businesses. 
I'll begin with storage systems, which includes both external storage systems and server RAID adapters and software. In our Storage Systems business, our first quarter revenues were the highest ever for the first quarter of the year. Building on Q4's record results, we now have two quarters in a row of record-revenue performance. Going forward, we are expanding our opportunities for continued growth. Healthy storage demand drivers are expected to fuel strong capacity growth, and these industry trends are aligned with our core capabilities.
Based on our analysis of IDC's storage systems tracker, we are the number one provider entry-level external storage systems through our OEM customers. Entry-level is the fastest growing Storage Systems segment. And in the second half of this year, we expect to ramp a new platform that will help us extend our leadership in this space. The new platform is based on LSI's highest performance 6-gig SAS storage processor and will offer up to 4x the performance and twice the capacity compared with our current industry-leading platform. It brings mid-range performance, connectivity and functionality to entry price points.
A key expansion opportunity in entry-level systems is in the white box market. IEC estimates that 42% of entry units are supplied by non-Tier 1 OEMs. This is a substantial opportunity for LSI to pursue a $1.6 billion a year market that we are not currently serving to our traditional OEM customers. Through our MegaRAID and 3ware products, we already served much of this segment, and our goal is to expand our presence by adding non-branded entry-level storage systems building blocks to our offerings in this channel. White box system builders will be able to integrate these storage building blocks into their branded product offerings.
We are also pleased with our competitive position at Oracle. Oracle recently posted a PDF on their website to address their partnership with Hitachi Data Systems. We believe there have been positive developments for LSI, including the termination of the HDS relationship. This will give LSI more room to grow, and Oracle also mentions support for technology partners associated with the 6780 system and 6000 series, which is all leveraging LSI storage system technology.
In our Server RAID [ph] (19:40) business, we continue to raise the bar relative to our competition by leveraging our leading SAS silicon in adding advanced data management capabilities. During the quarter, we announced four new data management offerings that will be released throughout this year aimed at addressing key end-user paying points. These were at fast path for boosting SSD I/O performance, safe store for data security, cascade for SSD data tiering and data snap and recovery, which is similar to snapshot and recovery available on external storage systems today.
I'll now turn to storage semiconductors, which includes the SAS, SAN and HDD. In SAS, we have the broadest portfolio solutions and continue to extend our leadership. Since the inception of SAS, LSI has shipped nearly 20 million SAS-based products across our full portfolio, which is over 10x more than the unit shipments of our nearest competitor. By offering best-in-class SAS technologies, assured interoperability and single-vendor support, LSI is the silicon-to-systems supplier of choice for top OEMs. In fact, at SNW, we demonstrated 1 million input-outputs per second with our PCIe-based solid-state storage solution in a single server, further demonstrating our performance leadership in this space.
Based on our broad portfolio and technology leadership, market-leading customers continue to choose LSI solutions. Our next-generation SAS ROCs and RAID software have already been chosen by two of the top three server x86 server OEMs for their 2011 Intel Romley generation servers. These wins positioned us well to secure Romley generation wins at other top server OEMs.
We have announced new products to further our growth in SAS. Our PCIe-based, solid-state storage solutions are under evaluation at 10 customers, and we have already secured the first design win. In addition, we sampled the industry's first series of 6-gig SAS switches to customers, which significantly extend the capabilities of SAS and direct-attached storage environments.
In external storage, we expect to gain share as SAS replaces Fibre Channel as the disk and host interconnect. Over five customers are using LSI's SAS bridge and expander solutions in external storage applications including Dell, Oracle, IBM, NetApp as well as Dot Hill.
Turning to hard disk drives. We are executing on all of the milestones we have set and are clearly position to grow SoC share as our solutions are increasingly deployed by customers. Our competitive position has dramatically improved since we accelerated our regional development cadence and hit the market inflection point with industry's first 40-nanometer LDPC solutions. The net result is that over the past several years, we have gone from being an SoC supplier to one customer to expanding our customer base with SoC wins at all five HDD OEMs.
Our HDD team is now focused on successfully executing on all of these new wins and key development programs. In fact, we've already taped out the first SoC for one of our new HDD customers. Now I would like to review the Networking business where LSI is bring a strong depreciation to customers.
The wireless segment in particular is the key focus area for LSI, where traffic levels are increasing dramatically driven by smartphones and portable PCs. Mobile data traffic is forecasted to grow at a compounded annual growth rate of over 100% between 2009 and 2014. This traffic management challenge becomes even more complex, with increasing levels of video content across the wireless network. To meet this challenge, carriers have to deploy new base station and media gateway architectures that delivers significant higher capacity and far greater capability at lower system costs and power. 
Last quarter, at Mobile World Congress, we announced and sampled our end-to-end next-generation wireless architecture and platform with three multi-core solutions for wireless applications: The Axxia communications processor, which paves the way for single multi-radio access network, StarPro media and based-band processor DSPs, which provide higher performance for video streaming, enabling higher traffic loads at lower costs and a new Link Communication Processor that allows network traffic to be easily and efficiently migrated from existing networks to next-generation Ethernet and IP networks. This portfolio of multi-processor cores is based on a scalable and unified architecture, which enables customers to drive common investments, resulting in more efficient development efforts. This foundational approach is creating multi-generational design wins for LSI key customers. All of the five top wireless infrastructure OEMs are currently using LSI products, and we expect this new portfolio of products to extend our footprint within these customers.
Last quarter, one of the top two wireless infrastructure OEMs shows our recently introduced Axxia processor for their next-generation, multi-radio-based stations and wireless gateway platforms. Now let me hand the call over to Bryon, who will take you through our results and provide guidance.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Abhi, and let me start by saying, we had a very strong Q1 2010. Seasonal buying patterns by enterprises typically caused a sequential decline in our first quarter revenues. However, we delivered first quarter revenues, which were sequentially flat
componenttext:
Thanks, Abhi, and let me start by saying, we had a very strong Q1 2010. Seasonal buying patterns by enterprises typically caused a sequential decline in our first quarter revenues. However, we delivered first quarter revenues, which were sequentially flat to Q4. First quarter revenues also represented a significant improvement relative to Q1 of 2009, when we were all experiencing the effects of the economic downturn. 
On a year-over-year basis, consolidated revenues were up 32%, consolidated gross margins excluding special items or up 500 basis points, operating margins excluding special items went from negative 1.7% to a positive 11.7%, operating cash flows improved $116 million, going from negative $10 million to positive $106 million. Our net cash balance was up 39% as compared to Q1 2009. In addition, we will be debt-free before the end of Q2.
During the downturn, we maintained a consistent focus on product development in support of a strong pipeline of design wins, while prudently managing expenses and sustaining a strong cash position. In addition to significantly beating the original Q1 guidance we provided in January, we met or exceeded the revised guidance we provided in March on revenue, gross margin and EPS. 
And now some highlights from the recent quarter. Revenues were $637 million, exceeding the midpoint of our increased guidance by $7 million and sequentially flat from Q4 2009. Consolidated gross margins, excluding special items, were 47.7%, improving sequentially by 30 basis points. Operating expenses, excluding special items, were approximately $229.5 million. Non-GAAP earnings were $0.14 per share, which is above the high end of our revised guidance range. We recorded a net tax benefit of $19 million in Q1, which included a favorable $28 million tax item, related to the expiration of statutes of limitations. If not for this item, we would have recorded non-GAAP EPS of approximately $0.10 per share, which is above the midpoint of our revised guidance. Operating cash flows were very strong at $106 million. And finally, total cash and short-term investments increased to slightly over $1 billion and net cash, or cash and short-term investments, net of total debt increased to $666 million.
And now turning to a more detailed discussion of the quarter beginning with revenues. Semiconductor revenues for Q1 were sequentially up $35 million or 9.2% to $416 million, significantly stronger than normal seasonality. In addition, revenues were up 28%, as compared to Q1 2009. Our Storage Semiconductor revenues, which include hard disk drives silicon, SAS standard components and storage area network ICs were sequentially up $12 million or 4.4% to $286 million. Storage Semiconductors represented 45% of total revenues in the first quarter. Q1 revenues in our Networking business were $114 million, sequentially up $19 million or 21% and represented 18% of total revenues for the quarter. Revenues for the IP business were up in the first quarter at $16 million. 
And turning now to our Storage Systems business, which includes both external storage systems and server RAID adapters and software, storage systems delivered a record Q1 in terms of revenues at $221 million. On a sequential basis, revenues for the Systems business were down $36 million or 14% from Q4 2009, primarily due to seasonality. This represented, however, a 40% improvement in Systems revenues as compared to Q1 2009. The Storage Systems segment represented 35% of LSI's total revenues in the first quarter.
Moving next to gross margins. LSI's consolidated Q1 gross margin, excluding special items, was 47.7%, which was sequentially up 30 basis points from Q4 '09. Semiconductor gross margins, excluding special items, sequentially increased 10 basis points from the fourth quarter to 52.0%. Storage Systems gross margins for the first quarter, excluding special items, sequentially declined 80 basis points to 39.8% primarily due to seasonally lower revenues.
Moving to operating expenses. R&D together with SG&A expenses, excluding special items, totaled $229.5 million in Q1. The sequential increase in Q4 is primarily due to the reinstatement of compensation and benefit programs we suspended early in 2009, along with lower relative spending in Q4, due to the vacations and shutdowns we had during the final quarter of 2009. Non-GAAP operating income, as a percentage of total revenues for the quarter, was 11.7% or $74.7 million. Interest income and other net of interest expense, excluding special items, was a loss of $1.1 million for Q1. 
And now, let me turn to the special items we recorded in the first quarter, which netted to $70 million. Special items, primarily non-cash, included $40 million in amortization of acquisition-related items, $16 million of stock-based compensation expense and $13 million of net restructuring costs and other items. Included in the $13 million of net restructuring costs and other items was a $12 million write-down of equity securities.
Moving next to tax. Our tax provision on both a GAAP and non-GAAP basis can vary significantly quarter-to-quarter, based on our profitability in different geographic tax jurisdictions and certain discrete items. Such a discrete item occurred in Q1, which relate  to the expiration of statutes of limitations. This release was excluded in the net tax benefit of $19 million we recorded in the quarter versus the $8 million tax provision we guided to in January. As noted earlier, if not for this item, we would've reported non-GAAP EPS of approximately $0.10 per share, above the midpoint of our revised guidance.
On a GAAP basis, first quarter net income was $23 million or $0.03 per share. Net profit, excluding special items, was $92 million or $0.14 per share. Keep in mind that both the GAAP and non-GAAP results recorded in Q1 include the above-mentioned $19 million tax benefit. 
Share count for the period for and GAAP purposes was 664 million shares and 690 million for non-GAAP purposes. The reported non-GAAP share count was higher than GAAP, due to the inclusion of 26 million shares related to our outstanding convertible debt when calculating non-GAAP EPS for the period, as a result of the non-GAAP profitability level.
And turning now to the balance sheet and cash flows. We continue building a solid cash position. First quarter operating cash flows were quite strong coming in at $106 million. A positive operating cash flow was driven primarily by operating performance, coupled with our continuous focus on efficient management of working capital. Our cash and short-term investments increased ending the March quarter at just over $1 billion. Relative to the $250 million share repurchase program we announced in March, we utilized $26 million to repurchase 4 million shares during the first quarter.
LSI's net cash position at the end of the quarter improved sequentially by approximately $54 million to $666 million. And finally, with respect to Q1 results, depreciation and software amortization was $26 million, and capital expenditures were $15 million.
The following is our guidance for Q2 2010: Revenues in the range of $635 million to $665 million. At the midpoint, this is sequentially up approximately 2%. We expect our Storage Systems business, along with our Storage and Networking Semiconductor businesses to be sequentially up in Q2. Consolidated gross margin, excluding special items, is expected to be 46.7% and 48.7%. We expect gross margins, excluding special items, to be approximately 52% for the Semiconductor segment and approximately 38% for the Systems segment.
Operating expenses, excluding special items, are expected to be in the range of $228 million to $238 million as we continue to invest, supporting our strong design win pipeline. Interest income and other and interest expense is expected to net to income of approximately $1 million. Special items are expected to net to approximately $50 million to $70 million. The GAAP and non-GAAP tax provision is expected to be approximately $9 million for Q2.
We expect Q2 GAAP net income per share in the range of negative $0.03 to positive $0.06 and EPS, excluding special items, to be in the range of $0.08 to $0.14. The share count is expected to be approximately 664 million shares for both GAAP and non-GAAP purposes. In addition, we expect depreciation and software amortization of approximately $26 million and capital expenditures of approximately $15 million. Also we will repay the $350 million of outstanding convertible notes when they mature in May. After which, LSI will be debt-free.
In conclusion, we are merging from the economic downturn well-positioned and excited about our prospects to drive growth going forward. Our focus for 2010 remains consistent: Deliver sustainable top and bottom line growth to drive continued progress towards are business model, continue to drive cash generation and maintain a solid balance sheet and drive continued design win momentum for future growth. And now let me turn the call back to Abhi.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bryon. Before we go to your questions, let me just reinforce that the management team is focused on making solid progress towards our business model. We have a number of catalyst for top line growth, initiatives for gross margin expansion, and
componenttext: Thank you, Bryon. Before we go to your questions, let me just reinforce that the management team is focused on making solid progress towards our business model. We have a number of catalyst for top line growth, initiatives for gross margin expansion, and expect to grow operating expenses at a lower rate than both revenue and operating income growth. Let me hand the call back to Sujal.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Two questions and both are on gross margins. Bryon, you said Systems gross margins will be down to 38%. Can you help us understand why?
componenttext: Two questions and both are on gross margins. Bryon, you said Systems gross margins will be down to 38%. Can you help us understand why?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, let me reinforce for everybody. In terms of our Q1 gross margin performance, which is very strong, we're already operating at or above our business model targets. Q1 was strong in what is typically a seasonally low quarter. As we think about
componenttext: First of all, let me reinforce for everybody. In terms of our Q1 gross margin performance, which is very strong, we're already operating at or above our business model targets. Q1 was strong in what is typically a seasonally low quarter. As we think about the progression to Q2, we see a few minor mix changes, as well as some benefits that we had in period costs in Q1 which revert back to more normal levels. For example, we had a lower-than-normal warranty costs in Q1, which drove significant gross margin performance in the quarter. We'll be having more typical levels in Q2. But let me reiterate, the Q2 gross margin guidance that we have for Systems at that approximate 38% range, we would consider it to be very good for that level of revenue and at this point time of the year, and we'd expect to kind of build from that point.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And my follow-up also on gross margins, at analyst day, you said for the full year, you're expecting 47%. Now it seems like two consecutive quarters, I mean, Q1 and Q2, where usually your gross margins are the lowest, you're above that range. So should we
componenttext: And my follow-up also on gross margins, at analyst day, you said for the full year, you're expecting 47%. Now it seems like two consecutive quarters, I mean, Q1 and Q2, where usually your gross margins are the lowest, you're above that range. So should we consider more than 48% for the full year? Or we should think of it differently?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we're not providing updated guidance for the full year gross margins. But clearly, given our performance in Q1, we're in a very strong position. We continue to maintain strong focus in terms of driving improvements, in terms of our productivity and
componenttext: Well, we're not providing updated guidance for the full year gross margins. But clearly, given our performance in Q1, we're in a very strong position. We continue to maintain strong focus in terms of driving improvements, in terms of our productivity and cost structure and so forth. And we're pleased with the fact that we're currently operating at or above the overall gross margin targets. So, yes, we'll keep -- and that will be a function, of course, of volume levels, product mix and continuing improvements in terms of our period expenses.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010

componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Blayne Curtis with Jefferies.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: The Networking business, you've been fighting a headwind there in trying to get above 100 million. You finally did. Can you maybe give a little color as to where the strength came from growth areas versus legacy?
componenttext: The Networking business, you've been fighting a headwind there in trying to get above 100 million. You finally did. Can you maybe give a little color as to where the strength came from growth areas versus legacy?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, we saw overall strength across both go forward, as well as legacy. I think the overall networking markets that we participate in saw a growth Q4 to Q1 because of the build-out, a lot of it in wireless. And I think some of our networking-cent
componenttext: Well, I mean, we saw overall strength across both go forward, as well as legacy. I think the overall networking markets that we participate in saw a growth Q4 to Q1 because of the build-out, a lot of it in wireless. And I think some of our networking-centric peers has also demonstrated good growth. We had even better growth because of the strength of our go-forward Networking business, which is both benefiting from end-demand environment improvements, but also share gains is more of our design-wins kick in the production. We also had better-than-anticipated legacy strength, as some of the phased out plans were delayed as people were chasing support for the wireless build-out that's been taking place. So I mean, those are the two major contributors to the strength of our business. But we're very happy with the progress in our go-forward networking areas.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I know you get asked this every quarter. But as far as the falloff, I mean, is there -- I know it's hard to predict that business, but are you still expecting that legacy business to fall off this year?
componenttext: Yes, and I know you get asked this every quarter. But as far as the falloff, I mean, is there -- I know it's hard to predict that business, but are you still expecting that legacy business to fall off this year?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, we had been saying at the beginning of the year that people should think about a $50 million to $70 million sort of drop over the course of the year, not necessarily providing quarterly guidance. I think, given where we're at, at this point in time
componenttext: Well, we had been saying at the beginning of the year that people should think about a $50 million to $70 million sort of drop over the course of the year, not necessarily providing quarterly guidance. I think, given where we're at, at this point in time of the year, it's likely going to be on the lower end of that range, but it's very difficult to say at this point in time. But I think that's what you should still be thinking about.

componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Craig Berger with FBR Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Craig Berger with FBR Capital Markets.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess one question I had is just also on the IP. What's the kind of forward outlook there? Is $16 million the new baseline?
componenttext: I guess one question I had is just also on the IP. What's the kind of forward outlook there? Is $16 million the new baseline?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, I'd say we have maintained a strong pipeline in terms of our IP opportunities. We have a good capability there. It's kind of vary from quarter-to-quarter. We remain committed to this goal of driving IP revenues on a year-over-year basis to be higher.
componenttext: No, I'd say we have maintained a strong pipeline in terms of our IP opportunities. We have a good capability there. It's kind of vary from quarter-to-quarter. We remain committed to this goal of driving IP revenues on a year-over-year basis to be higher. And I think we're very comfortable with how we've begun the year here.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, I guess, I'm just asking because you guys used to do in the 20s sometimes in that business. I'm just trying to figure out how to model out that line item this year.
componenttext: Well, I mean, I guess, I'm just asking because you guys used to do in the 20s sometimes in that business. I'm just trying to figure out how to model out that line item this year.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think, Craig, as we've talked to in several past calls, we've had some challenges over the prior three, four quarters relative to the IP business, just given the overall economic environment and the incremental challenge that that's presented in terms o
componenttext: I think, Craig, as we've talked to in several past calls, we've had some challenges over the prior three, four quarters relative to the IP business, just given the overall economic environment and the incremental challenge that that's presented in terms of getting value for our licensing activity. We are happy with where we started out this year. We said that we would grow this year relative to last year, and we feel good pretty good about being able to do that. And so we're guiding that up into the next quarter as well.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just a follow-up on the Storage IC business, you guys used to do in the kind of 300 to 330 range a quarter in 2008. Your guidance is going to get you back up to towards 300. When does some of these new design wins start to kick in that take us back to pri
componenttext: Just a follow-up on the Storage IC business, you guys used to do in the kind of 300 to 330 range a quarter in 2008. Your guidance is going to get you back up to towards 300. When does some of these new design wins start to kick in that take us back to prior peak or potentially even better? How long before we see some of that contribution?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think we're going to start seeing that contribution here fairly soon. Storage ICs, the number that you alluded to also included some of the older enterprise hard disk drive revenues that had been declining on us, which that headwind is completely
componenttext: Well, I think we're going to start seeing that contribution here fairly soon. Storage ICs, the number that you alluded to also included some of the older enterprise hard disk drive revenues that had been declining on us, which that headwind is completely gone and behind us now, and with the design wins that we secured over the past two years and those starting to come into production as we speak. And certainly, into the second half, we'll continue to see solid growth in this business across all segments within Storage segment.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've had a stronger-than-seasonal first half. Should we be thinking about a muted second half, given that elevated base? Or do you think we can continue to maybe track towards seasonal growth in the second half? Obviously, it's still kind of far away.
componenttext: We've had a stronger-than-seasonal first half. Should we be thinking about a muted second half, given that elevated base? Or do you think we can continue to maybe track towards seasonal growth in the second half? Obviously, it's still kind of far away.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I'm not going to give you guidance relative to the second half, but I'll give you my perspective and color. I mean second half for us, given an Enterprise-centric sort of composition, has generally been historically much stronger than the fir
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I'm not going to give you guidance relative to the second half, but I'll give you my perspective and color. I mean second half for us, given an Enterprise-centric sort of composition, has generally been historically much stronger than the first half, anywhere in the 10% to 12% sort of range. If I look at the second half at this juncture, what I would go by is overall, economic indicators are generally positive. Tech demand has certainly been recovering. Corporate spending relative to enterprise has still yet to really kick in. And then from an overall supply-demand standpoint, I'd say the supply line relative to demand has sort of aligned itself nicely. I'm not concerned about inventory. So all those things bode towards growth in the second half, but I'm not going to place a percentage number on that for you at this time.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Sukhi Nagesh with Deutsche Bank.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Sukhi Nagesh with Deutsche Bank.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: If you look back in history, you're second quarter has drawn an average of about 10%. I'm just trying to figure out, given your current guidance of flat to up 4%, can you just walk us through why we're kind of maybe below your historical average here?
componenttext: If you look back in history, you're second quarter has drawn an average of about 10%. I'm just trying to figure out, given your current guidance of flat to up 4%, can you just walk us through why we're kind of maybe below your historical average here?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean our historical average, if you go back over five years, wouldn't be 10%. I mean, certainly, there has been years here and there relative to just different cycles of product cycles and customer inventory situations. But if you really normalize
componenttext: Yes, I mean our historical average, if you go back over five years, wouldn't be 10%. I mean, certainly, there has been years here and there relative to just different cycles of product cycles and customer inventory situations. But if you really normalize those one-time things out, our Q1 to Q2 sort of growth has been sort of in the range that we're guiding Q2. And I think if you look at all the other proxies relative to PC and server growth, Intel being a good proxy, you look at our customers in the form of Seagate and WD, in fact, our guidance is a little bit better than what those proxies are guiding for their second quarter.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then for the June quarter guide in the top line, you said both the Storage Semi business, as well as Systems business, is expected to grow Q-on-Q. Where do you expect to decline? Do you expect Networking or IP to decline or...
componenttext: And then for the June quarter guide in the top line, you said both the Storage Semi business, as well as Systems business, is expected to grow Q-on-Q. Where do you expect to decline? Do you expect Networking or IP to decline or...

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, we're not expecting anything to decline. Certainly, the growth rates across these businesses vary, but all businesses are expected to grow Q1 to Q2.
componenttext: No, we're not expecting anything to decline. Certainly, the growth rates across these businesses vary, but all businesses are expected to grow Q1 to Q2.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Parag Agarwal with UBS.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Parag Agarwal with UBS.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just wanted to drill down on the gross margin for Semis. It appears that your Networking business is growing very fast. And given the design wins, it should continue to grow. So as that business grows and you have additional design wins sampling in the se
componenttext: Just wanted to drill down on the gross margin for Semis. It appears that your Networking business is growing very fast. And given the design wins, it should continue to grow. So as that business grows and you have additional design wins sampling in the second half, how should we thinking about your Semiconductor gross margin?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, Parag, our objective, and as we discussed at the analyst event, is to continue to drive our Semiconductor gross margins higher, right? We should be driving to higher levels in the 52% that we demonstrated in Q1. We're not going to put a time
componenttext: Well, I mean, Parag, our objective, and as we discussed at the analyst event, is to continue to drive our Semiconductor gross margins higher, right? We should be driving to higher levels in the 52% that we demonstrated in Q1. We're not going to put a timetable or a particular watermark out there that we're driving to. But the confidence that we have, I think, stems from the fact that we'll have increasing scale with our Semiconductor business, as SoC share gains continue to add to our revenue, our SAS business continues to grow, as well as your point, our Networking business. At this point in time of the year, we actually expect our Networking business in aggregate, inclusive of legacy to be positioned to grow as well in 2010. So all those things bode for improving Semiconductor gross margins. And I think we should be able to continue to drive that growth into 2011.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And coming to OpEx, at the analyst day, you said that OpEx is going to grow 1% to 2% for the quarter in 2010. Given the current outlook, you are still maintaining that target? Or is there any update with that?
componenttext: And coming to OpEx, at the analyst day, you said that OpEx is going to grow 1% to 2% for the quarter in 2010. Given the current outlook, you are still maintaining that target? Or is there any update with that?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, we're still very comfortable with what we said last month relative to operating expense growth in the course of the year. A key part of that was our commitment to drive top line and revenue growth, as well as operating income growth substantially ahea
componenttext: No, we're still very comfortable with what we said last month relative to operating expense growth in the course of the year. A key part of that was our commitment to drive top line and revenue growth, as well as operating income growth substantially ahead of OpEx. So yes, we definitely remain committed to that.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Daniel Amir with Lazard Capital Markets.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Daniel Amir with Lazard Capital Markets.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Lauren in for Daniel. Can you guys comment on the backlog and your visibility right now?
componenttext: This is Lauren in for Daniel. Can you guys comment on the backlog and your visibility right now?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Visibility for the second quarter is certainly good. Backlog, in terms of both backlog and turns, is sort of consistent with, I would say, past Q2s. In terms of visibility into the second half, certainly less visibility from that standpoint. But I'd go ba
componenttext: Visibility for the second quarter is certainly good. Backlog, in terms of both backlog and turns, is sort of consistent with, I would say, past Q2s. In terms of visibility into the second half, certainly less visibility from that standpoint. But I'd go back to the comments that I made to Craig Berger relative to our second half perspective.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just to be clear, you expect Networking IPs, Storage Semis and Semi to all be up next quarter?
componenttext: And then just to be clear, you expect Networking IPs, Storage Semis and Semi to all be up next quarter?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, that's correct.
componenttext: Yes, that's correct.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Allan Mishan with Brigantine.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Allan Mishan with Brigantine.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to clarify some of the comments you made in your prepared remarks about Storage Semis. So did you say that the SAN components was higher sequentially, but that HDD and SAS were down but above seasonal? Or were the latter two actually up as w
componenttext: I just wanted to clarify some of the comments you made in your prepared remarks about Storage Semis. So did you say that the SAN components was higher sequentially, but that HDD and SAS were down but above seasonal? Or were the latter two actually up as well?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: No, we said that HDD and Storage Systems was sort of above seasonal, right? Basically, all segments were above seasonal. But in terms of HDD and Storage Systems, we said that they were in line with sort of end-market growth, whereas our storage and server
componenttext: No, we said that HDD and Storage Systems was sort of above seasonal, right? Basically, all segments were above seasonal. But in terms of HDD and Storage Systems, we said that they were in line with sort of end-market growth, whereas our storage and server compliments, which is inclusive of SAN, actually outgrew the market Q4 to Q1.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then in your Q2 guidance, do you include the ramp of any new enterprise SoC programs? Or is that something that could be upside if it takes place?
componenttext: And then in your Q2 guidance, do you include the ramp of any new enterprise SoC programs? Or is that something that could be upside if it takes place?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's insignificant. No, it's small.
componenttext: It's insignificant. No, it's small.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Hans Mosesmann with Raymond James & Associates.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Hans Mosesmann with Raymond James & Associates.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Abhi, can you give us a sense of what you're seeing in the channel and at OEMs in terms of inventories? And what is your opinion on your current inventory position, how you would expect that to trend here over the next quarter?
componenttext: Abhi, can you give us a sense of what you're seeing in the channel and at OEMs in terms of inventories? And what is your opinion on your current inventory position, how you would expect that to trend here over the next quarter?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I would say inventories are in pretty good shape. Still probably not quite at model, but there was some further inventory replenishment that took place throughout the quarter. But I would say, across most of our product lines and the visibility that
componenttext: Yes, I would say inventories are in pretty good shape. Still probably not quite at model, but there was some further inventory replenishment that took place throughout the quarter. But I would say, across most of our product lines and the visibility that we have in the customers, I'd say inventories still quite not at model revenue relative to a lot of the different segments. This is why we're confident that we don't have an inventory situation. And then in terms of channel, when I think about channel, I think about sort of the white box channel that services 20%, 30% of the server market. There, we've seen great sell-through. And there, I would say that we're right about at model for inventories. So no concerns there from an inventory standpoint.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Harlan Sur with JPMorgan.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Harlan Sur with JPMorgan.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Within your Storage Systems business, you're doing quite well on the entry-level side. I think, Abhi, you said number one in market share now. Just curious as to how the margins for these products compare with the margins for your Midrange systems?
componenttext: Within your Storage Systems business, you're doing quite well on the entry-level side. I think, Abhi, you said number one in market share now. Just curious as to how the margins for these products compare with the margins for your Midrange systems?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, the margins, it depends because we've got different business models with our different customers. Some take complete systems, some take just controllers and so forth. We're not going to break out the margins in particular for those. The soft
componenttext: Well, I mean, the margins, it depends because we've got different business models with our different customers. Some take complete systems, some take just controllers and so forth. We're not going to break out the margins in particular for those. The software attached also is a factor. So it's a bit of a complicated question, and it's not something we're going to provide a level of granularity on. Now I want to also comment that our Midrange business has done very well also. The last three quarters, especially relative to our combined efforts between LSI and IBM, we've seen solid Midrange growth, growth faster in the market, share gains in this particular space. If I look at our high-end Midrange product and in terms of its mix in Q1 of 2010 versus 2009, significantly higher, significant year-over-year units growth. It also tells me that end customers are starting to buy up again. And it's a pattern that we've now seen for several quarters.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess along those -- just sort of a feeling on top of that, so of the incremental growth that you've seen in your Midrange Systems business, how much of that is just enterprise and IT spending and sort of capacity build-outs versus sort of the success t
componenttext: I guess along those -- just sort of a feeling on top of that, so of the incremental growth that you've seen in your Midrange Systems business, how much of that is just enterprise and IT spending and sort of capacity build-outs versus sort of the success that you're seeing and market share gains with the new Midrange platforms?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's both. Certainly, the demand around the world has been up in storage, but we've also seen incremental benefits from share gains.
componenttext: It's both. Certainly, the demand around the world has been up in storage, but we've also seen incremental benefits from share gains.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Again, on the Storage Systems businesses, you guys have done a pretty good job at improving margins. Actually, in the overall business over the past few years, just curious, what kind of activities do you guys have in place to be able to kind of further t
componenttext: Again, on the Storage Systems businesses, you guys have done a pretty good job at improving margins. Actually, in the overall business over the past few years, just curious, what kind of activities do you guys have in place to be able to kind of further tick up margins here going forward?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I think it's some of the same things that we've talked about before. Software attach continues to be a big focus. We're starting to see a very good traction in the marketplace with our relationship with HP, where they sell our Storage Virtualization
componenttext: Well, I think it's some of the same things that we've talked about before. Software attach continues to be a big focus. We're starting to see a very good traction in the marketplace with our relationship with HP, where they sell our Storage Virtualization and advance sort of copy services solutions for EDA. We're seeing great traction there. That's largely a software-oriented sale that comes with very nice margins. So software has certainly been a big portion as we continue to scale and grow our overall revenue that helps in terms of absorption rates and improves gross margins as well. And where we can, we're certainly looking at just evolving the overall business model where we increasingly shift more of the array controllers, the fiberglass, silicone and software versus necessarily a lot of sheet metal, if you will, right? So those are the different things that we're working on relative to gross margin and initiatives to improve our Systems gross margin.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Mark Heller with TLFA (sic) [CLSA].
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Mark Heller with TLFA (sic) [CLSA].

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'm not sure you've covered it, but why did the inventories go up 10% in the quarter on the balance sheet?
componenttext: I'm not sure you've covered it, but why did the inventories go up 10% in the quarter on the balance sheet?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, so the inventories are up. But if you look at that compared to historical levels compared to a year ago, if you had look at what that represents in terms of turns, we're very comfortable with the inventory levels that we have. There maybe a few cases
componenttext: Yes, so the inventories are up. But if you look at that compared to historical levels compared to a year ago, if you had look at what that represents in terms of turns, we're very comfortable with the inventory levels that we have. There maybe a few cases where we wanted to ensure supply to make sure that we could service our customers. But I think we're comfortable not only with the performance that we drove in the first quarter, but really our position as we move to the year 2010.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, the inventory levels are far below what the peak prior to the downturn. We continue to have best-in-class turns in our inventory. It's not a concern, whatsoever.
componenttext: Yes, the inventory levels are far below what the peak prior to the downturn. We continue to have best-in-class turns in our inventory. It's not a concern, whatsoever.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: And can you update us on the -- I know that you've been talking about an enterprise win ramp in the hard drive space. Can you just give us an update on a that and when that was?
componenttext: And can you update us on the -- I know that you've been talking about an enterprise win ramp in the hard drive space. Can you just give us an update on a that and when that was?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean the specificity of that really needs to be -- that question needs to really go towards our customer. But in terms of what we said where initial units would start shipping in the first half and then a ramp starting towards the latter part of th
componenttext: Yes, I mean the specificity of that really needs to be -- that question needs to really go towards our customer. But in terms of what we said where initial units would start shipping in the first half and then a ramp starting towards the latter part of the first half and growing strength into the second half, we continue to believe that, that will be the case.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your next question is from the line of Sanjay Devgan with Morgan Stanley.
componenttext: Your next question is from the line of Sanjay Devgan with Morgan Stanley.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess the first pertains to given the better-than-normal seasonality we've seen from a broad base of semiconductor companies, I guess the biggest question on most people's minds are kind of the tight capacity, both from the foundries, as well as from te
componenttext: I guess the first pertains to given the better-than-normal seasonality we've seen from a broad base of semiconductor companies, I guess the biggest question on most people's minds are kind of the tight capacity, both from the foundries, as well as from test-and-assembly perspective. Just wanted to get your thoughts, given that the second half of the year normally is, as I think you pointed out, it's up 10% to 12% in aggregate relative to the first half. How comfortable are you with your ability to source product, both from a foundry and test-and-assembly perspective?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say that if I was to measure the tightness of the supply chain over the past three, four months, it still remains very tight. But the level, the number of escalations and so forth has certainly been reduced, but we still continue to see that. We'v
componenttext: I would say that if I was to measure the tightness of the supply chain over the past three, four months, it still remains very tight. But the level, the number of escalations and so forth has certainly been reduced, but we still continue to see that. We've been working very closely with our major suppliers to ensure sufficient capacity and sufficient allocation of that capacity throughout the rest of this year. And at this point in time, we feel like we're generally in good shape to be able to meet all demand.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Abhi, you talked about the growth in the Networking business this last quarter, being broad-based across both of your focused products, as well as the legacy products. I was wondering, as we look at the legacy products, if you could remind us what end mar
componenttext: Abhi, you talked about the growth in the Networking business this last quarter, being broad-based across both of your focused products, as well as the legacy products. I was wondering, as we look at the legacy products, if you could remind us what end markets those products cater to you today? I'm assuming they're mainly ASICs, but if you could just help us understand what end markets there they're geared to, that would be helpful.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I'd say there's a decent concentration in wireless, and that's one of the reasons that we saw better-than-expected strength. Some of the older products just continue to ship as people, people as in telecom equipment companies, had to respond to carrier's
componenttext: I'd say there's a decent concentration in wireless, and that's one of the reasons that we saw better-than-expected strength. Some of the older products just continue to ship as people, people as in telecom equipment companies, had to respond to carrier's demands to build up more capacity, especially in the strange sort of wireless networks. A large part of it is also in sort of the backhaul, which is also an area that's been a focus in terms of improving the overall capacity and bandwidth out there for wireless networks that are under a lot of strain, given things like the iPhone. So it's many different parts across a lot of different designs and applications in customers. But I would say, there is certainly a piece of it that is driven by wireless, and that's why we saw the upside.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: By wireless, you mean GSM, GPRS legacy?
componenttext: By wireless, you mean GSM, GPRS legacy?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes.
componenttext: Yes.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Your final question is from the line of Jim Schneider with Goldman Sachs.
componenttext: Your final question is from the line of Jim Schneider with Goldman Sachs.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is Mark Delaney calling in from Jim Schneider. I guess starting off first with respect to your hard drive customers. Are you getting any near-term benefits from delays in program transitions, and specifically maybe your comments that Seagate, if you'
componenttext: This is Mark Delaney calling in from Jim Schneider. I guess starting off first with respect to your hard drive customers. Are you getting any near-term benefits from delays in program transitions, and specifically maybe your comments that Seagate, if you're able to pick up any share there from STMicro?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I mean, as we've said, and I'll just go back to what color we've provided relative to our Seagate relationship, we are their largest supplier today. We expect our business at Seagate to grow, and we also expect our share to grow there. And a lot of
componenttext: Well, I mean, as we've said, and I'll just go back to what color we've provided relative to our Seagate relationship, we are their largest supplier today. We expect our business at Seagate to grow, and we also expect our share to grow there. And a lot of this also stems from the fact that we started winning sole SoC wins that date back now over 18 months. And some of these are going to start coming into production.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: You guys have talked a lot about supply and demand being on pretty healthy balance, generally. I was wondering if you could drill down into the storage adapter. I think maybe some of your customers have been reporting mixed results. I mean just wondering
componenttext: You guys have talked a lot about supply and demand being on pretty healthy balance, generally. I was wondering if you could drill down into the storage adapter. I think maybe some of your customers have been reporting mixed results. I mean just wondering on what you're thoughts are in the component levels in that segment specifically?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I mean, I think you're probably referring to Emulex and referring to Fibre Channel adapters to be specific. I mean, I assume that's what you're referring to. Inventory situation there seems to be consistent with sort of past patterns. There is a bit
componenttext: Yes, I mean, I think you're probably referring to Emulex and referring to Fibre Channel adapters to be specific. I mean, I assume that's what you're referring to. Inventory situation there seems to be consistent with sort of past patterns. There is a bit of a phase shift that occurs now and then. There's also a transition of 4 gig to 8 gig that is occurring, nothing that we're necessarily concerned about. In the case of the customer that you alluded to, I think their results also were reflected based on sort of IBM's Power Systems or pSeries business, which did drop year-over-year by 17%. But that's relatively a small part of our overall Fibre Channel SAN business. So it's nothing that we're concerned with.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q1 2010 Earnings Call, Apr 28, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would like to thank all of you for joining us this afternoon. If you have additional questions, please call Investor Relations at LSI. Thank you, and have a nice day.
componenttext: I would like to thank all of you for joining us this afternoon. If you have additional questions, please call Investor Relations at LSI. Thank you, and have a nice day.
