headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the LSI Corporation Investor Relations Conference Call. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. Later, we will conduct a question-and-answer session. Instructions will be given
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the LSI Corporation Investor Relations Conference Call. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. Later, we will conduct a question-and-answer session. Instructions will be given at that time. As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Sujal Shah, Vice President of Investor Relations at LSI. Please go ahead.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon and thank you for joining us. With me today are Abhi Talwalkar, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Bryon Look, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.Abhi will begin the call with some opening remarks and highlights
componenttext:
Good afternoon and thank you for joining us. With me today are Abhi Talwalkar, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Bryon Look, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer.
Abhi will begin the call with some opening remarks and highlights from our business, and then Bryon will provide results and guidance for the fourth quarter of 2010.
During this call, we’ll be mentioning non-GAAP financial measures, which we may refer to as results excluding special items. Today’s earnings release describes the differences between our non-GAAP and GAAP reporting. You can find reconciliations of our non-GAAP financial measures to corresponding GAAP amounts on our Web site at www.lsi.com/webcast.
At that site you will also find a copy of the earnings release and a presentation highlighting the key points from today’s call and providing an overview of our business; this may be particularly useful to investors who are new to LSI.
I want to remind you that today’s remarks will include forward-looking statements. Our actual results could differ materially from those suggested by the statements made today. Information about factors that could affect our future results is contained in our Form 10-Q for the quarter ended July 4, 2010, and our Annual Report on the Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2009.
With that it is my pleasure to introduce Abhi Talwalkar.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon and welcome. I am pleased with how our team executed in Q3 delivering non-GAAP EPS above the midpoint of our guidance range even in a challenging demand environment where revenues were impacted. As a management team, we continued to execute
componenttext:
Good afternoon and welcome. I am pleased with how our team executed in Q3 delivering non-GAAP EPS above the midpoint of our guidance range even in a challenging demand environment where revenues were impacted. As a management team, we continued to execute on the factors we can control to improve our operating margins.
On a non-GAAP basis, we delivered gross margins above the high end of the guidance and above business model and demonstrated continued operating expense control. As a result, we expanded operating margins to 13% and delivered EPS of $0.13 per share. We also had solid operating cash flows of 82 million and were active in buying back stock during the quarter.
Overall, LSI revenues came in at $629 million, which was towards the low end of our guidance range. Softness was driven largely by declines in shipments of hard disk drive SoCs precipitated by well publicized challenges in the hard disk drive end market and associated inventory burn, as well as the anticipated inventory adjustments at our customers in our fibre channel SAN and SAS business. We saw our storage systems business grow quarter-over-quarter and our networking investment areas posted solid sequential growth.
Now I want to review additional business highlights for Q3 including details on new product cycles. I’ll begin with Storage Systems, which includes both external storage systems and server RAID adapters and software.
Our external storage systems business continued to grow in Q3 as IT shops added capacity to meet their digital content growth. We have been expanding our business through a multi-pronged approach encompassing new platform introductions, growth in existing OEM partnerships, and diversification of our customer base and channels.
We’ve seen strong adoption of our recently introduced entry level 2600 storage platform achieving the fastest volume ramp for a new storage platform in our history. The 2600 is now being shipped by seven of our top OEM customers with several more scheduled to launch before the end of this year.
Our midrange segment also saw growth at multiple OEMs. Existing customers such as IBM, Teradata, Dell and SGI all contributed to our sequential growth and are expected to deliver overall growth in Q4 as well.
At IBM, we have solidified roadmap commitments to extend LSI solutions into 2011 and beyond. In the entry segment, IBM launched the DS3500 series, and in the midrange segment, we are releasing new software extensions and new family members to the DS5000 series.
As you may be aware, IBM recently extended its midrange offering with the announcement of the Storwize V7000. This is a complementary offering that is positioned above the DS5000, which is sourced from LSI.
IBM has always maintained a broad portfolio of storage products to address a wide range of customer needs and customers have chosen LSI solutions in the midrange because of our field-proven reliability, exceptional price performance, and broad availability.
We’ve been driving customer expansion through the development of new OEMs that add application and channel value on top of our systems. This category includes companies such as BlueArc, Quantum, ZTE, Cray, IBM’s cloud and analytics offerings and a number of other OEMs. This category delivered growth this quarter and is expected to grow for the full year.
In an effort to further diversify and grow our business, in Q3 we began shipping a family of unbranded configurable storage system building blocks into the white box distribution channel, which represents a large TAM expansion opportunity.
The reception has been exceptional as we look to ramp our business into this new customer base that has reach into small, medium, government as well as large internet data centers.
I’ll now shift to our server RAID adapter and software business serving the direct-attached storage market, in which we grew over 30% year-over-year. This growth exceeded server unit growth due to OEM share gains at IBM and our expanded presence in the channel through the combination of our MegaRAID and 3ware product families.
DAS technology has clearly had a resurgence driven by data center architectures, larger virtualized server environments, as well as the advent of Flash tiering.
I’ll now turn to storage semiconductors which includes SAS, SAN and HDD. In SAS, we have the broadest portfolio of solutions and continue to extend our leadership position into the Intel Romley generation of servers launching in 2011.
IBM has chosen our next generation SAS ROC and RAID software for their high volume xSeries server product line. Dell and Cisco have already chosen LSI ROC devices and RAID software for their Romley generation servers, and we have made significant progress at another leading server OEM for future SAS products. LSI solutions continue to be chosen over the competition including integrated chipset solutions that are being offered in the SAS space.
To further extend our SAS leadership and add to top line growth, we are also bringing two new products to market, which expand our portfolio beyond silicon and RAID adapters. Our SAS switch and solid state storage adapters have both been launched with wins in Tier 1 OEMs.
Turning to hard disk drives, we are solidly position to grow SoC share as our solutions become increasingly deployed by customers. In the third quarter, we began ramping SoCs in the Seagate Savvio and Constellation enterprise drives.
We expect to expand our footprint to additional enterprise drives at Seagate as we go forward. We are also shipping SoCs into Hitachi’s ULTRASTAR enterprise offering.
Last quarter, we sampled four different 40-nanometer LDPC base solutions to multiple customers across the industry, and have begun ramping with one customer.
In addition to custom solutions, we now have introduced and sampled a fully LSI developed 40-nanometer standard product SoC for notebook and desktop platforms. This SoC integrates LSI’s hard disk controller, LDPC read channel, serial PHY, and firmware.
Finally, we have already started on our 28-nanometer platform to ensure we have a robust roadmap of products available for our customers into the future, which is a proof point of our technology leadership.
Now, I’d like to review the networking business, where we continue to experience strong momentum driven by our major product lines, which are network processors, DSPs, and custom products.
In Q3, our revenues in networking investment areas grew 13% sequentially and 69% year-over-year, a direct result of prior design wins materializing into revenue.
In wireless infrastructure, we are growing through market share gains and benefiting from the global expansion of 3G and 4G networks. We are currently designed into or shipping custom products for wireless base stations at Nokia Siemens, Alcatel-Lucent, Huawei and ZTE.
Network processors also exhibited strong growth year-over-year led by sales into Ericsson’s flagship, RBS base station line. We expect to continue to grow share in network processors as we go forward.
In enterprise networking, we’re growing in Ethernet connectivity, data center and voice and video gateway applications. We are in production with the leading PC and server chipset company for custom gigabit Ethernet devices and have shipped over 10 million units year-to-date. This establishes a beachhead and we expect to expand Ethernet solutions for client and server applications.
For Ethernet connectivity in the data center, we are supplying a custom 10 gigabit Ethernet solution for server applications to Emulex in the product line that was formerly server engines.
DSPs which enable high density voice and high definition video are shipping in Cisco’s new ISR routers. Lastly, LSI have sampled custom silicon for next generation data center switches which will go into production in the second half of 2011.
Before I turn it over to Bryon for financials, I want to stress two key points on LSI’s investment proposition. First, as we look beyond the current year and into 2011 we have a number of new product cycles that can contribute to revenues even if we remain in a challenging economic environment.
In hard disk drives, we have begun ramping enterprise SoCs at Seagate and we’ll expand to additional enterprise platforms as we move through 2011.
In the second half of next year, we also expect to gain share in client platforms at Seagate. In SAS, we expect IBM, Dell and Cisco to ramp Romley generation servers with LSI solutions and expect to see ramps in our new solid state storage adapters.
In networking, we expect greater contribution from base station and enterprise custom products, network processors, and DSPs as we ramp new applications serving the wireless enterprise segments. In systems, we expect to continue to gain share in entry level platforms, while expanding our customer base in the midrange.
Second, this management team is committed to making continued progress towards business model target of 17% non-GAAP operating margins, while also enabling sustained top line growth into the future.
While we can’t control end demand or the ordering patterns of customers, we will continue to drive initiatives aimed at expanding gross margins and controlling operating expenses to drive increased operating leverage.
The long-term fundamentals of our business are solid, our large and growing multi-year design win pipeline continues to move into and towards production, and we continue to deepen our engagements with market leading customers to establish growth drivers for the future.
Now, I’ll turn the call over to Bryon, who will take you through our results and provide guidance.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Abhi, and thanks everyone for joining the call today. Throughout 2010, we’ve continued making progress towards the business model. Non-GAAP gross margins expanded from 47.7% in Q1 to 49.3% in Q3.We effectively held non-GAAP operating expenses
componenttext:
Thanks, Abhi, and thanks everyone for joining the call today. Throughout 2010, we’ve continued making progress towards the business model. Non-GAAP gross margins expanded from 47.7% in Q1 to 49.3% in Q3.
We effectively held non-GAAP operating expenses flat to down for the year, while supporting an increased level of design activity to drive future revenue growth. We’ve driven non-GAAP operating margin expansion from 11.7% in Q1 to 13.1% in Q3.
In addition, on a year-to-date basis, we delivered $256 million of positive operating cash flows, repaid all of our remaining debt, repurchased approximately 46 million shares, and still closed the most recent quarter with a cash balance in excess of $600 million. These metrics are clear indicators of solid progress on our operating performance while maintaining a strong balance sheet.
Let’s shift now to a more detailed discussion on the quarter, beginning with revenues. Total revenues for Q3 were $629 million, sequentially down 1.6% and up 9% on a year-over-year basis.
Semiconductor revenues for Q3 were $390 million, sequentially down 6% from Q2, and up 5% on a year-over-year basis. Our storage semiconductor revenues were sequentially down $30 million or 11% to $242 million.
This decline was primarily driven by weakness in the HDD end market and associated inventory burn of SoCs at our customers, as well as the anticipated inventory adjustments at our fibre channel SAN and SAS customers. Storage semiconductors represented 38% of total revenues in the third quarter.
Q3 revenues in our networking business were $119 million, sequentially down $3 million or 2%, and represented 19% of total revenues for the quarter. Growth in our networking investment areas was offset by declines in legacy products. Revenues for the IP business were up in the third quarter at $29 million.
Turning now to our storage systems business which includes both external storage systems and server RAID adapters and software. Storage systems revenues were sequentially up 7% to $239 million. This represented a 16% improvement in systems revenues as compared to Q3 2009. The storage system segment represented 38% of LSI’s total revenues in the third quarter.
Moving next to gross margins; LSI’s consolidated Q3 gross margin excluding special items was 49.3%, sequentially up 90 basis points from Q2 and approximately 180 basis points above the midpoint of our guidance. A key contributor to the non-GAAP gross margin improvement was semiconductor product mix, which included sequentially higher IP revenues.
Semiconductor gross margins, excluding special items sequentially increased approximately 120 basis points from the second quarter to 55.3%. Storage systems’ gross margins for the third quarter, excluding special items sequentially improved 180 basis points to 39.5%.
Moving to operating expenses; R&D together with SG&A expenses excluding special items were sequentially down $4 million to $228 million in Q3, consistent with the midpoint of our guidance.
Non-GAAP operating margin sequentially improved by approximately 90 basis points to 13.1% or $82 million. This was a 400 basis point improvement on a year-over-year basis, further demonstrating the continued progress towards our business model targets.
Interest income and other net of interest expense, excluding special items was a gain of approximately $5 million for Q3.
Now, let me turn to the special items we recorded in the third quarter, which netted to $56 million. Special items, primarily non-cash, included $40 million in amortization of acquisition related items and $17 million of stock-based compensation expense.
Moving next to tax, for Q3, we reported a provision of $8.1 million for both GAAP and non-GAAP, which was consistent with the guidance we provided in July. As a reminder, our tax provision on both a GAAP and non-GAAP basis can vary significantly from quarter-to-quarter based on our profitability in different geographic tax jurisdictions and discreet items.
On a GAAP basis, third quarter net income was $23 million, sequentially improving from $0.01 to $0.04 per share. Net income, excluding special items was $79 million, sequentially improving from $0.11 to $0.13 per share. Share count for the period was 634 million shares for both GAAP and non-GAAP purposes.
Turning now to cash flows and the balance sheet; operating cash flows in the third quarter were $82 million and were $256 million year-to-date. We exited Q3 with cash and short-term investments balance of $601 million.
During the quarter, we utilized approximately $137 million of cash for share repurchases. Year-to-date, we have repurchased a total of 46 million shares and utilized $218 million under the current share repurchase authorization.
Finally, with respect to Q3 results, depreciation and software amortization was $27 million and capital expenditures were $11 million.
The following is our guidance for Q4, 2010; revenues in the range of $635 million to $665 million. At the midpoint, this is sequentially up 3%. We expect both our networking and storage semiconductor businesses to be flat to slightly down relative to Q3, while we expect our storage systems business to be sequentially up.
Consolidated gross margin excluding special items is expected to be between 47% and 49%. We expect gross margins excluding special items to be approximately 54% for the semiconductor segment and approximately 40% for the systems segment.
Operating expenses excluding special items are expected to be in the range of $223 million to $233 million, which is sequentially flat at midpoint. Interest income and other and interest expense is expected to net to income of approximately $3 million.
Special items are expected to net to approximately $50 million to $70 million. The GAAP and non-GAAP tax provision is expected to be approximately $10 million for Q4.
We expect Q4 GAAP net income per share in the range of negative $0.01 to positive $0.08, and EPS excluding special items to be in the range of $0.10 to $0.16 per share. The share count is expected to be approximately 620 million shares for both GAAP and non-GAAP purposes. In addition, we expect depreciation and software amortization of approximately $27 million, and capital expenditures of approximately $15 million.
Before we go to your questions, I just want to underscore our commitment to drive to business model performance. While the end demand environment has a certain degree of uncertainty, we have a number of new product cycles that will contribute to our top line performance as we go forward.
In addition, we are running above our business model goals on gross margin and expect to maintain tight control on operating expenses to improve our earnings growth.
I would now like to turn the call back to Sujal.

componenttextpreview: Good afternoon. Thanks for taking my question. I was wondering if you could begin by kind of addressing the inventory situation broadly at your customers, and maybe by segment, if you can talk about where do you think like adapter component inventories ar
componenttext: Good afternoon. Thanks for taking my question. I was wondering if you could begin by kind of addressing the inventory situation broadly at your customers, and maybe by segment, if you can talk about where do you think like adapter component inventories are as well as hard drive component inventories, and then any other commentary on the adapter hardware, or other hardware side would be great. Thank you.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Okay. Let me take a shot at that. At a high level, it certainly appears that supply and demand are in balance, however, it’s really hard to know, given we’ve had that perspective before, and have been surprised by ordering patterns, but if I go a litt
componenttext:
Okay. Let me take a shot at that. At a high level, it certainly appears that supply and demand are in balance, however, it’s really hard to know, given we’ve had that perspective before, and have been surprised by ordering patterns, but if I go a little bit deeper, the SAS inventory that we talked about in the last call, in particular with one customer we believe that that has been addressed and that is expected to resume and match sort of demand in the server environment.
Relative to the fibre channel, silicon inventory that was at our fibre channel adapter customers, we believe the majority of that has been addressed. There may be a little bit that gets cleaned up in the fourth quarter, but the majority has been addressed. Relative to hard disk drives, again that appears to be fairly balanced relative to supply/demand based on a TAM assumption base that has units being flattish from Q3 to Q4.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then maybe as a follow-up, could you talk a little bit about, two things, number one is, what do you expect the IP revenue to do going forward, obviously a pretty substantial jump in the quarter. How should we think about that going forward? And then
componenttext: And then maybe as a follow-up, could you talk a little bit about, two things, number one is, what do you expect the IP revenue to do going forward, obviously a pretty substantial jump in the quarter. How should we think about that going forward? And then just on a separate notes, what about OpEx. How long can you keep it flat at these levels? Are you going to wait for revenue growth to come back in a big way before you bring OpEx back or how are we thinking about investment levels for next year?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me take the IP question, and then I’ll have Bryon respond to the OpEx question. Relative to IP, I think people should continue modeling a $20 million to $25 million sort of revenue level for IP. I’m very pleased with what we’ve done with the IP
componenttext: Let me take the IP question, and then I’ll have Bryon respond to the OpEx question. Relative to IP, I think people should continue modeling a $20 million to $25 million sort of revenue level for IP. I’m very pleased with what we’ve done with the IP revenue stream. We’ve built it back up post-merger to sort of this $20 million, $25 million level. Big part of this success has also been some pretty significant licensing agreements that were closed very recently that will bring even more stability into that revenue base and give us confidence to hit the $20 million per quarter to $25 million per quarter.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and relative to operating expenses, I think you can expect us to continue to manage our operating expenses very carefully. If you look at the course of 2010, we managed to be able to hold those operating expenses flat to even slightly down. Our goal
componenttext: Yes, and relative to operating expenses, I think you can expect us to continue to manage our operating expenses very carefully. If you look at the course of 2010, we managed to be able to hold those operating expenses flat to even slightly down. Our goal is to continue to drive to our business model performance, and that means that we’re going to expect to drive our operating income faster than the operating expenses are allowed to grow.

componenttextpreview: Thanks for taking my question. Just wanted to build on further in your guidance, you said that the storage semis are going to be down a bit and also networking semis. So just wondering what part of storage semis you would expect to be down, especially tha
componenttext: Thanks for taking my question. Just wanted to build on further in your guidance, you said that the storage semis are going to be down a bit and also networking semis. So just wondering what part of storage semis you would expect to be down, especially that one would expect kind of strong seasonality for at least SAN and SAS business, and also your networking business, can you talk about your legacy versus investment business?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, we didn’t give color at a granular level. We said our overall semiconductor business is going to be flat to slightly down, if you kind of break it up a little bit. First of all, we think it’s generally very consistent with the end markets that we
componenttext: Yes, we didn’t give color at a granular level. We said our overall semiconductor business is going to be flat to slightly down, if you kind of break it up a little bit. First of all, we think it’s generally very consistent with the end markets that we’re in as well as some of the proxy companies that we look at and our biggest customers, hard disk drives which is certainly a major part of our overall semiconductor. Hard disk drive TAM is expected to be flat quarter-to-quarter in terms of units. You can factor in a little bit of ASP erosion in there, so that sort of addresses that. From a networking standpoint, if you look at a lot of our peers that are heavily exposed in networking, most of those guys were negative, actually quite a bit negative into the low to mid, even high single-digits. So again, I think we’re tracking relatively well in the networking space.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, and I also wanted to get more color on networking. Could you highlight your design wins especially in the wireless infrastructure, and I mean I am really surprised by the strength in your networking business, so any color will be really helpful here?
componenttext: Yes, and I also wanted to get more color on networking. Could you highlight your design wins especially in the wireless infrastructure, and I mean I am really surprised by the strength in your networking business, so any color will be really helpful here?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: The strength in the networking business, it comes in two flavors. If I look at the go forward or sort of the investment areas in networking, that’s going to have very strong year-over-year, not only at the quarter, which we said were 69%, but for the fu
componenttext:
The strength in the networking business, it comes in two flavors. If I look at the go forward or sort of the investment areas in networking, that’s going to have very strong year-over-year, not only at the quarter, which we said were 69%, but for the full year looking at sort of what’s factored into our midpoint, will be in excess of 50% year-over-year growth. What’s driving that is a lot of the design wins that we’ve been winning over the last two to three years that are materializing and moving into production. Our network processors are fairly heavily used across a number of the players in the base station category. We also have a number of custom silicon implementations that perform various functions in both base stations as well as RNCs.
So, whether it’s a custom product or standard product, we have some piece of silicon that’s going into I think most of the wireless infrastructure providers, right, and there is five of them that pretty much dominate the entire marketplace. So, that’s been a big part of what’s driving networking and we’re now starting to come into revenue that’s being materialized from design wins that we won several years ago in the enterprise space, whether it’s the custom 5 Ethernet products or whether it’s the 10-gig product that we discussed. So it’s a really a number of things that we’re starting to see kick in.

componenttextpreview: Sukhi, you’re right. We had a very solid quarter once again in terms of gross margin performance. I think this probably represents the 5th consecutive quarter of gross margin expansion. We are operating above our business model targets which consolidate
componenttext:
Sukhi, you’re right. We had a very solid quarter once again in terms of gross margin performance. I think this probably represents the 5th consecutive quarter of gross margin expansion. We are operating above our business model targets which consolidated that target at 47% and we’ve been operating clearly above that. I would say that comment also applies to both semiconductor as well as systems.
If you look at our guidance for Q4, on that Q4 guidance, again, is operating above business model with the systems business being approximately 40% and our semiconductor gross margins roughly in the range of about 54%, 55%. So, I guess relative to expectations going forward, we’re going to continue driving towards our business model and gross margins will be a part of that. We do have ongoing efforts underway on the cost side to continue to make improvements over time.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Any comments on mixture? And then again I have a follow-up on the operating margin side.
componenttext: Any comments on mixture? And then again I have a follow-up on the operating margin side.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: No specific guidance yet for 2011, but clearly I think with increased revenues, that’s going to be a contributor to the ability to drive gross margin expansion, and again as I mentioned, we have cost initiatives underway. I will point out that mix plays
componenttext: No specific guidance yet for 2011, but clearly I think with increased revenues, that’s going to be a contributor to the ability to drive gross margin expansion, and again as I mentioned, we have cost initiatives underway. I will point out that mix plays into this certainly. We had strong contributions in the current quarter in Q3 from IP and we’re very pleased with the growth that we’ve seen in our IP revenues. But you may see some variance from quarter-to-quarter just based in terms of mix, and one of the points relative to just the Q4 guidance is you see the mix of stronger systems growth in the quarter which is reflected again in that 47% to 49% that we have for this quarter. But, I think it’s been a good story and we’ll remain focused in that area.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: A follow-up; on the operating margin side, could you remind us or highlight to us what percentage of your operating expenses is kind of variable versus fixed? In other words, one thing, it’s pretty hard for you guys to, for anybody these days to actuall
componenttext: A follow-up; on the operating margin side, could you remind us or highlight to us what percentage of your operating expenses is kind of variable versus fixed? In other words, one thing, it’s pretty hard for you guys to, for anybody these days to actually determine what revenue is going to look like, so I’m trying to figure out if there is a way that you can achieve your operating margin goal at lower revenue levels? Thanks.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would answer the question by saying that we’re going to keep operating on all lines to be able to move to business model target relative to the different components of that. I think getting to those targets will be had by driving top line growth. We
componenttext: I would answer the question by saying that we’re going to keep operating on all lines to be able to move to business model target relative to the different components of that. I think getting to those targets will be had by driving top line growth. We’ve got strong support there, gross margin performance there, and relative to operating expense, continuing to hold that and manage it as carefully as we can.

componenttextpreview: We are just now starting production shipments into the two drive families that we discussed. There are plans in place and efforts underway to move into additional enterprise drives within Seagate over the course of next year as well. If you think about th
componenttext: We are just now starting production shipments into the two drive families that we discussed. There are plans in place and efforts underway to move into additional enterprise drives within Seagate over the course of next year as well. If you think about the overall TAM for enterprise hard drives, it’s around 20 million to 25 million units for a full year, probably closer to roughly 25 million or so, maybe slightly above that. Seagate has roughly 65 plus per cent share, and Hitachi is sort of the next biggest share player who is probably in the high teens, maybe low 20s or so. We’re not going to breakout specifically the share expectations at Seagate, but just based on the plans that we have as well as what they have relative to this SoC, it’s moving across all enterprise drive offerings.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the client side, Abhi, you also mentioned that you have an opportunity at Seagate, and then you talked about the merchant or the standard product SoC. I am just wondering if you have any update for us on that and also if you can briefly touch upon the
componenttext: On the client side, Abhi, you also mentioned that you have an opportunity at Seagate, and then you talked about the merchant or the standard product SoC. I am just wondering if you have any update for us on that and also if you can briefly touch upon the SSD opportunity as we look out to the next few quarters.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: On the client side, clearly we’ve been in development for several years and if you piece together the time to revenue cycle for the enterprise drive SoC, we won that back in middle of ‘07, it is now in the third quarter, started shipping its first pro
componenttext:
On the client side, clearly we’ve been in development for several years and if you piece together the time to revenue cycle for the enterprise drive SoC, we won that back in middle of ‘07, it is now in the third quarter, started shipping its first production systems, production hard drives. So it can be anywhere from a 2 to 3 year cycle. Similarly, we are now also starting to ship production SoCs in the client space that we won a number of years ago and we’ll start to see that come online at a stronger ramp in 2011 and in particular in the second half of 2011 where we expect to gain more client share across the desktop and notebook space.
Relative to SSDs, again as we’ve discussed SSDs in the past, our primary focus is around customized flash controllers for enterprise SSDs from some of the major players that are offering SSDs and developing enterprise SSDs. Relative to the client SSD or the notebook SSD, we’ve been opportunistic there, and we do have a development in that space that we’ve talked about in previous calls.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: One quick one for Bryon. Bryon on the share buybacks, just wondering, given your share count guidance, I am assuming you will continue to buyback. Just wondering how much of the buybacks are left, and then any other plans for the $600 million in net cash
componenttext: One quick one for Bryon. Bryon on the share buybacks, just wondering, given your share count guidance, I am assuming you will continue to buyback. Just wondering how much of the buybacks are left, and then any other plans for the $600 million in net cash that you have?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Relative to share repurchases, we were based on them obviously very active in the quarter, and since we’ve been granted that authorization. Year-to-date, we’ve utilized about $218 million of the $250 million authorized by the Board for share repu
componenttext:
Yes. Relative to share repurchases, we were based on them obviously very active in the quarter, and since we’ve been granted that authorization. Year-to-date, we’ve utilized about $218 million of the $250 million authorized by the Board for share repurchases. And I think as we go forward, we’ll continue to look at share repurchases amongst the various usage for that cash. We’re very pleased with the cash performance that we continue to drive for the company.
I noted in a discussion earlier, cash flow performance was good not only in the quarter but year-to-date over $0.25 billion of positive operating cash flow. So that gives us a lot of flexibility relative to do things like share repurchase, and of course, we’re also operating at this point with no debt. So in the past, we were using some of that cash to repay the debt outstanding, but we no longer have any convertible notes outstanding.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Afternoon, guys. Couple of questions. First, Bryon, on the gross margin you’ve done a great job on storage systems; you are kind of close back to your prior peaks there. Can you, one, just talk about what drove the strength in Q3 was it product mix, sof
componenttext: Afternoon, guys. Couple of questions. First, Bryon, on the gross margin you’ve done a great job on storage systems; you are kind of close back to your prior peaks there. Can you, one, just talk about what drove the strength in Q3 was it product mix, software or such, and then kind of how to think about that going forward particularly now that you’re kind of at some record levels likely in Q4 and going forward in storage volumes?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think the team has done a great job with respect to driving cost down and also obviously we get a benefit from the growth that we saw and continue to see in that business. So given that we’ve been operating at close to or at business model target
componenttext: Yes. I think the team has done a great job with respect to driving cost down and also obviously we get a benefit from the growth that we saw and continue to see in that business. So given that we’ve been operating at close to or at business model targets going forward, we’ll continue to focus in those areas. I think we’re not to the point where we want to change our business model targets for our systems gross margins, and that’s baked into the guidance obviously that we’ve provided. For 2011, I think it’s probably too early for us to provide any kind of color there.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then just secondly for, Abhi, on the SAS side, you named some wins on Romley, can you just give us some perspective as to how you see your share playing out with that refresh? Is it increasing, decreasing, staying flat, any color will be helpful?
componenttext: And then just secondly for, Abhi, on the SAS side, you named some wins on Romley, can you just give us some perspective as to how you see your share playing out with that refresh? Is it increasing, decreasing, staying flat, any color will be helpful?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Let me answer the question in two different ways. If I look at overall SAS technology base, which is inclusive of SAS controllers, SAS ROC, SAS expanders, as we go through that Romley generation of servers as well as external storage systems that are empl
componenttext: Let me answer the question in two different ways. If I look at overall SAS technology base, which is inclusive of SAS controllers, SAS ROC, SAS expanders, as we go through that Romley generation of servers as well as external storage systems that are employing SAS, we absolutely expect to gain share. If I just focus and zero in on SAS ROCs and SAS controllers relative to servers, and within the servers, our expectation is that inflection point will also allow us to gain share from where we’re at that. But we feel we’ve been very confident, I think over the last two, three calls of our competitive position on our next generation of SAS ROCs and controllers as well as the competitive lead that we have.

componenttext: Hi. The end demand for hard disk drives are likely to remain weak in the near-term. Can you remind us when LSI can see material revenue contribution from some of your new SoC customers such as Western Dig?

componenttext: Well, I won’t respond specifically to Western Digital. I think your question, if I can rephrase it is, we’ve got a certain exposure to hard disk drive SoCs today across the mix of desktop, notebook and enterprise. And clearly, we talked about enterprise as we start ramping in Seagate, we’ll start to see greater exposure and greater share. On the client slide, we’re going to start seeing that start in the first half of 2011, and much more meaningful in terms of share gains relative to the second quarter half of 2011, just based on product cycles.

componenttextpreview: Systems is doing well. Can you comment what you’re thinking in terms of expanding the addressable market? You mentioned unbranded, you’re selling some unbranded product in the white box market, any plans of a branded product in the channel or how you
componenttext: Systems is doing well. Can you comment what you’re thinking in terms of expanding the addressable market? You mentioned unbranded, you’re selling some unbranded product in the white box market, any plans of a branded product in the channel or how you’re thinking of expanding that addressable market?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, as we said in the prepared remarks, Kaushik, we’ve been driving a diversification expansion of that business for probably three, four years, right, across a number of different ways. If I look at Teradata today versus Teradata two, three years ago
componenttext:
Well, as we said in the prepared remarks, Kaushik, we’ve been driving a diversification expansion of that business for probably three, four years, right, across a number of different ways. If I look at Teradata today versus Teradata two, three years ago, substantially different, much more meaningful contributor. Dell three years ago was really not a major contributor, now is a meaningful contributor. We’ve been broadening the OEM base that we sort of pursue as the emerging sort of Tier 2 OEM base that are adding various forms of value on top of our storage systems, that’s been a driver of the growth.
So, the other thing that we’ve recently been working on, we started piloting some activity in the fourth quarter last year and this third quarter this year is when we finally announced and launched some products into the sort of the white box reseller channel. There is $0.5 billion to $1 billion sort of market opportunity there that we think can be served very well by unbranded building blocks. The resellers will integrate those at their specific channel value, and we’ll have an opportunity to make some pretty interesting margins as well. Those will be unbranded. There are no plans to do a branded offering.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Guys, nice job on the cost controls. Can you comment on the IP revenues, why were they up so much and how sustainable is the space as we look forward into 2011?
componenttext: Guys, nice job on the cost controls. Can you comment on the IP revenues, why were they up so much and how sustainable is the space as we look forward into 2011?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: First of all, remember the IP revenues Craig are lumpy, right, because we’ve got lots of deals in the pipeline and it’s a matter of which deals can we close in the quarter. So, there is always going to be lumpiness. I want to just reiterate what I sai
componenttext:
First of all, remember the IP revenues Craig are lumpy, right, because we’ve got lots of deals in the pipeline and it’s a matter of which deals can we close in the quarter. So, there is always going to be lumpiness. I want to just reiterate what I said earlier, $20 million to $25 million per quarter is what should be the input for models that are out there.
I think the other thing that I want to sort of add is, given some of the annuity streams that we’ve built up over the last one to two years, pretty meaningful closure of a licensing agreement in the third quarter that we highlighted, which was fairly meaningful in terms of size as well as future annuities gives us a nice foundation going into every year that gives us confidence in our ability to hit the $20 million $25 million window consistently.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: My follow-up question is; I am looking at 2010 versus 2008 for your storage business and your networking business, your storage chips, and I am just wondering if something has changed in that business. To me it looks like storage revenues are going to be
componenttext: My follow-up question is; I am looking at 2010 versus 2008 for your storage business and your networking business, your storage chips, and I am just wondering if something has changed in that business. To me it looks like storage revenues are going to be down this year versus 2008 more than networking. You guys have talked about a legacy bleed going on there, PC units are growing. You’re consolidated share in hard drive so I am wondering what the disconnect is?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: I don’t think, there is a disconnect. First of all, in 2008, we still had pretty substantial piece of enterprise HDC legacy in that storage semiconductor business which we don’t enjoy today at all and it was pretty sizeable in 2008, roughly in the ord
componenttext:
I don’t think, there is a disconnect. First of all, in 2008, we still had pretty substantial piece of enterprise HDC legacy in that storage semiconductor business which we don’t enjoy today at all and it was pretty sizeable in 2008, roughly in the order of $200 million, okay? So, you take that $200 million out of that base in 2008, the business has done well.
Relative to networking and networking legacy and sort of go forward, networking legacy at that point in time in 2008 was $260 million for the full year. It’s roughly $140, $150 million this year, so there is another $100 million. I think that’s one of the biggest challenges that we’ve had as a transforming company is how do you really pull out and show the growth that has been occurring given one or two of these elements that have masked that underlying growth. There is an abundance of proof points that these design wins are materializing and delivering revenue and hence supporting underlying growth.
The networking go forward area which I alluded to growing well in excess of 50% year-over-year for the full year, 70% almost for quarter-over-quarter is just one of a number of examples, right, and as we start to further emerge out of this deep investment cycle and start to see some of the bigger design wins materialize, that will help us drive 2011 growth and certainly 2012 growth.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: One more question please, which is, with storage being down two quarters in a row or tepid two quarters in a row, how do we think about Q1 seasonality there for our models and have you seen any stabilization or improvement in orders in recent weeks?
componenttext: One more question please, which is, with storage being down two quarters in a row or tepid two quarters in a row, how do we think about Q1 seasonality there for our models and have you seen any stabilization or improvement in orders in recent weeks?

headline: LSI Corporation, Q3 2010 Earnings Call, Oct 27, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think we’ve seen stabilization Craig, and the last two quarters in storage semis and even our fibre channel SAN, I guess that’s part of the storage semis, has really been clouded by the linearity issues that we’ve experienced over the first t
componenttext:
Yes. I think we’ve seen stabilization Craig, and the last two quarters in storage semis and even our fibre channel SAN, I guess that’s part of the storage semis, has really been clouded by the linearity issues that we’ve experienced over the first three quarters of the year. Year-over-year, the performance has been in line at or above markets relative to those businesses. In terms of sort of go-forward, we certainly believe that we’ve seen stabilization. Clearly, it’s anyone’s guess as to what end markets do, but everyone is sort of triangulating to a flat TAM in the fourth quarter.
As to Q1 and Q1 seasonality, Q1 typical seasonality for LSI is down 8% to 10%. However, that’s off of a typical fourth quarter seasonal budget flush that can drive our revenues 8% to 10% up, and we’re muted in terms of that seasonality in the fourth quarter. So, it’s possible that there could be a muted sort of decline in the first quarter and maybe we’re closer to mid single-digits versus high single-digits in terms of a decline.

componenttextpreview: I mean I think some of the things that we outlined in the prepared remarks, we certainly see share gains in the hard disk drive space, both in terms of SoCs and preamps, supported by ramps in enterprise drives within Seagate as well as improvement in our
componenttext:
I mean I think some of the things that we outlined in the prepared remarks, we certainly see share gains in the hard disk drive space, both in terms of SoCs and preamps, supported by ramps in enterprise drives within Seagate as well as improvement in our client position in the second half of 2011 in terms of share. We certainly see that being a driver for incremental above market sort of top-line growth rate.
We certainly see further ramp into the custom 5 gigabit solutions that we have with the one customer that we’ve talked about. We’ve won numerous programs at that customer and only I believe two have sort of started ramping and they’re still in the early stage of ramping. So, we expect considerably more units to ship next year, and that will also drive growth. And then we’ve got a number of networking solutions, both standard product and custom that will also start to ship in production systems at our customers.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the LSI Corporation Investor Relations Conference Call. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. Later, we will conduct a question-and-answer session. Instructions will be given
componenttext:
Ladies and gentlemen, thank you for standing by. Welcome to the LSI Corporation Investor Relations Conference Call. At this time, all participants are in a listen-only mode. Later, we will conduct a question-and-answer session. Instructions will be given at that time. As a reminder, this conference is being recorded.
I would now like to turn the conference over to your host, Sujal Shah, Vice President of Investor Relations at LSI. Please go ahead.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Good afternoon and thank you for joining us. It looks like we had some technical difficulties to start the call, so we apologize for that. But we're going to get going I knew some folks are still dialing in as we speak, but with me today are Abhi Talwalka
componenttext:
Good afternoon and thank you for joining us. It looks like we had some technical difficulties to start the call, so we apologize for that. But we're going to get going I knew some folks are still dialing in as we speak, but with me today are Abhi Talwalkar, President and Chief Executive Officer; and Bryon Look, Executive Vice President and Chief Financial Officer. Abhi will begin the call with some opening remarks and highlights from our business and then Bryon will provide results and guidance for the third quarter of 2010.
During this call, we will be mentioning non-GAAP financial measures which we may refer to as results excluding special items. Today's earnings release describes the differences between our non-GAAP and GAAP reporting. You can find reconciliations of our non-GAAP financial measures to corresponding GAAP amounts on our website at www.lsi.com/webcast.
At that site, you will also find the copy of the earnings release and a presentation, which highlights the key points from today's call and provides an overview of our business. This may be particularly useful to investors who are new to LSI.
I want to remind you that today's remarks will include forward-looking statements. Our actual results could differ materially from those suggested by the statements made today. Information about factors that could affect our future results is contained in our annual report on Form 10-Q for the quarter ended April 4, 2010 in our annual report on the Form 10-K for the year ended December 31, 2009.
With that, it is now my pleasure to introduce Abhi Talwalkar.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you. Good afternoon and welcome. In Q2, our revenues were 639 million representing a slight increase from Q1. Also in Q2 and on a non-GAAP basis, gross margins were at the high end of the guidance range above Q1 levels and above our business model g
componenttext:
Thank you. Good afternoon and welcome. In Q2, our revenues were 639 million representing a slight increase from Q1. Also in Q2 and on a non-GAAP basis, gross margins were at the high end of the guidance range above Q1 levels and above our business model goals.
Operating expenses came in below the midpoint of guidance, and we generated operating income expansion. We also have solid cash flows eliminated our debt, and we're active in buying back stock during the quarter. I'm pleased with how our team executed in Q2 delivering non-GAAP EPS at the midpoint of the guidance range even with revenues at the low end of the rand.
Now, I would like to put our near-term revenues in perspective. Our Q2, in Q2 we had solid year-over-year growth across all our businesses and grew faster than the majority of the end markets we participated. Our server-related businesses, which includes SAN, SAS and server blade solutions in aggregate, grew 40% year-over-year well ahead of server unit growth rates for the same period.
Our total networking business grew 23% year-over-year exceeding respective end market growth with investment areas in networking growing in excess of 50% year-over-year. And our systems business grew 13% year-over-year, also exceeding end market growth.
There are three dynamics of our influence in our sequential revenues in Q2 and Q3. First, we outperform some of our markets in our Q1, and are seeing in inventory adjustment from several customers in Q2 and Q3 as a result. Second, in the HDD business we saw a softening in demand late in Q2.
While the softening seems to have stabilized, we have seen a reduction in industry TAM and build plans particularly in desktop which commonly drives a higher portion of LSI's SoC revenues. This soften reach to more modest growth expectations in Q3, lastly we expect to see sequential declines in our non-investment areas in networking this quarter.
To drill down further our semiconductor revenues were up 9% sequentially in Q1 which was considerably higher growth than most of our peers and proxies for the end markets we participate in.
In retrospect, our out performance in Q1 was partly driven by our SAN and SAS customers building inventory ahead of technology transitions. This led to unit shipment reductions in SAS and SAN in Q2 and continued weakness in SAN shipments in Q3 to bring supply in line with end demand for those customers.
While our hard disk drive revenues are primarily from the desktop segment today, our recent SoC wins will expand our OEM base to customers more exposed to the faster growing notebook segment.
We believe these wins are our major step towards achieving our long-term goal of greater than 40% share of the ACD SoC market in the future.
Our Q2 results and Q3 guidance are simply reflections of these dynamics and not any loss of share in any of our businesses. In fact based on our year-over-year performance we have gained share in most of the markets we share.
As we look forward into Q4 based on our current industry projections for the HCD server and storage systems markets combined with near term inventory adjustments we expect to realize high single digit percentage revenue growth in Q4 of this year from Q3 levels.
Going forward the management team is committed to making continued progress towards our business model target of 17% non-GAAP operating margins. While we can't control end demand or the ordering patterns of our customers, we will take action on things we can control to improve operating leverage.
Earlier in the year we said that we would grow non-GAAP expenses at approximately 1 to 2% per quarter. Our goal now is to maintain expense levels below $230 million per quarter in both Q3 and Q4 of this year representing a reduction from Q2 levels.
We continue to expect full year non-GAAP gross margins to above our operating model target of 47% and our targeting non-GAAP operating income expansion for this year.
The long-term fundamentals of our businesses are solid, our design momentum is robust and we continue to deepen our engagements with market leading customers. During the quarter, we secured meaningfully design wins with customers like Dell and Cisco.
We remain confident and in our ability to grow our businesses at a rate exceeding the growth rate in the markets we serve. In addition, we recently completed a litigation settlement and cross-licensing deal with Samsung which we believe increases the certainty and visibility into our near term IP revenues.
Now, I want to review with you the business highlights for the last quarter. I will begin with storage systems which includes both external storage systems and server RAID adapters and software.
Our overall external storage systems business grew slightly ahead of the market from a year-over-year standpoint. We continue to expand our business to a new platform introductions OEM partnerships and design wins.
In this business we are uniquely positioned to respond to often shifting OEMs, partners, internal investments and storage with a range of solutions from turnkey storage systems to high value software controllers and high density drive enclosures. This approach has enabled our systems business to expand its customer base with consistent growth while navigating the constantly changing storage systems landscape, evolving roadmap and investment strategies of our OEMs.
Continuing our successful partnership with IBM, in Q2 we solidified road map commitments to extend LSI solutions into 2011 and beyond. In the entry segment, IBM just launched the DS3500 series to a solid end customer reception. In the midrange segment we are on track to release later this year and early next year several new software extensions and new family members to the popular DS5000 midrange storage family.
Additionally in our mid-range business we saw growth in our 4900 storage system platform, new OEM wins and high performance computing, expanding sales in our 60 drive high-density enclosure as well as solid sequential improvements in our sales to Oracle.
Based on our analysis of IDC's storage systems tracker for the first quarter of 2010 we remain the number one provider of entry-level external storage system shipments through our OEM customers. Entry level remains the fastest growing storage system segment and IBM, Dell and SGI are all now ramping our new volume and performance entry platforms that enable midrange performance at highly competitive price points. Teradata and Cray are also ramping the new platform as part of their integrated solutions for data warehousing and high performance computing.
As we mentioned in the last quarter, a key expansion opportunity for us in entry-level systems is in the white box market segment which is a $1.6 billion a year segment that we are not currently serving. In the second quarter we introduced the CTS2600 as a configurable storage building blocks which not only add to our growth prospects but also enable us to further diversify the business.
Now shifting to our server rated after business, we experienced significant year-over-year growth, well ahead of end market growth rates. Our share gains came from fully ramping across IBM's xSeries servers while firmly maintain our RAID solutions in nine of the top ten server OEMs.
We also gained share in the white box reseller channel through the combination of our MegaRAID and 3ware product families. Last month we announced that Gartner ranked LSI first overall in worldwide host bus RAID controller units for the third year in a row.
I'll now turn to storage semiconductors which include SAS, SAN and HDD. In SAS we have the broadest portfolio of solutions and continue to extend our leadership. Last quarter we mentioned that our next generation SAS Rocks and RAID software have already been chosen by two of the top three x86 server OEMs for their 2011 Intel Romley Generation Servers.
These wins position us well to secure Romley Generation wins at the other to server OEMs. We believe that we have established a significant lead over the competition. In fact a recent press release by one of our competitors confirms that LSI is nearly seven months ahead with our solutions. Based upon the claims and our competitor's press release, LSI will remain the clear performance leader for server solutions.
Regarding the PCIe flash solution we announced earlier this year, we have over 50 samples in evaluation and validation and more than 20 customers. Testing and feedback has been very positive regarding the product's performance and efficiency in comparison to other PCIe flash solutions in the market. We will be ramping production throughout the second half of 2010.
Turning to hard disk drives we are solidly positioned to grow SoC share as our solutions are increasingly deployed by customers. We recently announced the production shipments of the industry's first low-density parity check or LDPC solution.
With Seagate we have enabled the industry's first hard disk drives with LDPC SoCs in 65 nanometer technology. The long-standing relationship between Seagate and LSI has delivered innovative, best in class solutions over many technology generations.
As a further proof point of successful execution in the HDD arena, we have now shipped first silicon for four unique 40 nanometer LDPC SoCs to three different HCD customers. We are pleased that we're executing to our engineering milestones with all the programs we have in development. The HCD industry will be moving towards 40 nanometer and LDPC, and LSI is in a leadership position with this technology.
It is worthwhile to point out that many of our large notebook, many of the large notebook OEMs in the HCD space are currently sole sourced with our competitors. As the industry move towards the dual source model, we expect that our notebook penetrate increases from current levels fueling our growth.
Now I'd like review the networking business where we continue to expand our position with the industry's leading OEMs and the service providers, and enterprise networking infrastructure segments. Our investment areas and networking grew over 50% year-over-year in the second quarter illustrating our continued traction with market leading customers in the product areas that will drive future growth.
The wireless infrastructure segment is in particular focus for LSI where we are in production with all of the top five OEMs and continue to benefit from the demand for 3G and 4G wireless networks. Adding to our progress, the new AXIA communication processor began sampling in Q1, and we announced that one of the top two wireless infrastructure OEMs chose AXIA for their next generation wireless platforms.
In Q2, we secured multiple new AXIA design wins including a win with a leading wireless infrastructure structure OEM for 3G and 4G applications. Our unique ability to blend custom and standard solutions allowed us to secure a design win with ZTE on their base stations.
In addition, our new generation of multi-core media processors was selected for one of the industry's highest volume wireless media gateway platforms. Overall, customer traction and engagement with our enterprise networking products is extremely strong. We have conveyed our design win momentum at Cisco with our DSP products, which have now entered production on multiple platforms.
We continue to expand our design win momentum at Cisco in other areas such as data center switching, routing and security applications that leverage both our custom silicon and unique multi-core product portfolio. We also continue to make meaningful progress with custom solutions in the Ethernet connectivity space.
Our previously announced custom gigabit Ethernet 5 designs have been shipping in volume in client applications at the key customer. In addition, we now have intercepted the 10-Gig E data center transition by ramping a 10-Gigabit Ethernet laying on the motherboard and server blade solution with an emerging leader in this segment that has solid traction with a number of tier-one server OEMs.
We've also won a Next-Generation NG based T custom design for server applications with the same customer. Now I'll turn the call over to Bryon who will take you through our results and provide guidance.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks Abhi. Let me start by summarizing some key bullets highlighting our progress in delivering solid financial results and driving actions design to further expand shareholder value. On a year-over-year basis, revenues improved 23%, and we are well poi
componenttext:
Thanks Abhi. Let me start by summarizing some key bullets highlighting our progress in delivering solid financial results and driving actions design to further expand shareholder value. On a year-over-year basis, revenues improved 23%, and we are well poised to benefit from design wins ramping in the near future.
Non-GAAP gross margins expanded by 630 basis points. We continued to focus on a variety of initiatives to expand margins, which have contributed substantially to this improvement. In addition, we have delivered above business model performance for non-GAAP gross margin for three consecutive quarters.
Non-GAAP operating margin expanded from 2.5% in Q2 of 2009 to 12.1% in this most recent quarter. We have now delivered three consecutive quarters of double-digit non-GAAP operating margin. Shifting to operating expenses, we continue being diligent on spending delivering a non-GAAP operating expenses below the midpoint of our guidance for the second quarter and we expect to maintain this focus as you will see in our guidance.
In terms of cash and the balance sheet, operating cash flows improved by $114 million or nearly tripling in the first half of the year compared to the first of 2009. This performance contributed to a 28% improvement in our net cash balance on a year-over-year basis even after our recent share repurchases.
We have also been active in buying back shares using $81 million to repurchase 14 million shares in the first half of 2010. At our current stock price we continue to view share buybacks as a good use of cash and a way to return value to shareholders.
In addition, during the quarter LSI repaid it's only remaining debt obligation and we are now debt free. Now some highlights from the recent quarter, revenues were $639 million within our guidance range and relatively flat to Q1, 2010.
Consolidated gross margins excluding special items were 48.4% improving sequentially by 70 basis points. Operating expenses, excluding special items were approximately $232 million. Operating margin, excluding special items sequentially improved by 40 basis points to 12.1%, non-GAAP earnings were $0.11 per share which is at the mid-point of our guidance range.
Operating cash flows were $68 million and finally we close the quarter with $670 million in total cash and short-term investments. Now turning to a more detailed discussion on the quarter beginning with revenues, semiconductor revenues for Q2 were $417 million sequentially flat to Q1.
Our storage semiconductor revenues which include hard disk drive silicon, SAS standard components and storage area network ICs were sequentially down $14 million or 5% to $272 million. As noted earlier in the call this decline was primarily driven by inventory builds and customer buying patterns in Q1.
Storage semiconductors presented 43% of total revenues in the second quarter. Q2 revenues in our networking business were $122 million sequentially up $7 million or 6% and represented 19% of total revenues for the quarter.
Revenues for the IP business were up in the second quarter at $23 million. Turning now to our storage systems, business which includes both external storage systems and server RAID adaptors and software.
Storage systems delivered another strong quarter in terms of revenues which were sequentially up 1% to $223 million. In addition, this represented a 26% improvement in systems revenues as compared to Q2, 2009.
The storage systems segment represented 35% of LSI's total revenues in the second quarter. Moving next to gross margins, LSI consolidated Q2 gross margin excluding special items was 48.4% and sequentially up 70 basis points from Q1.
This result included a favorable impact resulting from the termination in the quarter of a supply arrangement which improves consolidated non-GAAP gross margins by approximately 90 basis points.
Semiconductor gross margins excluding special items sequentially increased 200 basis points from the first quarter to 54.0%. Approximately 140 basis points of this improvement was due to the supply arrangement I just noted as it related to our semiconductor business. Storage systems gross margins for the second quarter excluding special items sequentially declined 210 basis points to 37.7%, primarily due to higher period costs and mix.
Moving to operating expenses, R&D together with SG&A expenses, excluding special items totaled $232 million in Q2, approximately $1 million below the midpoint of our guidance, non-GAAP operating margin sequentially improved by 40 basis points to 12.1% or $77 million. Interest income and other net of interest expense, excluding special items was a gain of $3 million for Q2.
Now let me turn to the special items we recorded in the second quarter which netted to $64 million. Special items, primarily non-cash included $40 million in amortization of acquisition related items, $18 million of stock based compensation expense and $5 million of net restructuring costs and other items.
Moving next to tax, for Q2 we recorded a provision of $9 million for both GAAP and non-GAAP which was consistent with the guidance we provided in April. As a reminder our tax provision on both a GAAP and non-GAAP basis can vary significantly from quarter-to-quarter based on our profitability in different geographic tax jurisdictions and discreet items.
On a GAAP basis, second quarter net income was $7 million or $0.01 per share. Net profit excluding special items was $71 million or $0.11 per share. Share count for the period was 662 million shares for both GAAP and non-GAAP purposes.
Turning now to the balance sheet and cash flows, operating cash flows in the second quarter were $68 million, and were $173 million for the first half of the year. The positive operating cash flow was driven primarily by operating performance, coupled with our continued focus on efficient management of working capital.
During the quarter we repaid the remaining $350 million of outstanding convertible notes and ended the period debt free with a cash and short-term investments balance of $670 million. Our cash position and balance sheet remains strong and we are well positioned to support the business going forward. Finally with respect to Q2 results, depreciation and software amortization was $26 million and capital expenditures were $13 million.
The following is our guidance for Q3 2010; Revenues in the range of 625 to $655 million. At the mid point, this is sequentially flat to Q2. This is primarily driven by a couple of key areas in our semiconductor businesses.
First are the accelerated customer buying patterns and resulting inventory builds we experienced in the first half of the year, primarily in our SAN and SAS businesses which will get worked down in Q3. Second, our expectations for the HDD business are fairly consistent with the trends in that market with our business being currently influenced by a heavier exposure to desktop HDDs.
Given this, we expect storage semiconductors to be sequentially flat to slightly down in Q3. We expect networking semiconductors to be sequentially down, primarily due to declines in legacy product sales. We expect our storage systems business to be sequentially noted.
As Abhi noted, based on current industry projections for the HCD, server and storage systems market combined with near-term inventory adjustments, we expect to realize high single-digit percentage revenue growth in Q4 of this year from our Q3 levels.
Consolidated gross margin excluding special items is expected to be between 46.5 and 48.5% in the third quarter. We expect gross margins excluding special items to be approximately 52% for the semiconductor segment, and approximately 39% for the systems segment.
Operating expenses including special items are expected to be in the range of $223 million to $233 million. At a midpoint of 228 million, this would represent a 1.6% sequential decline in our operating expenses. This reflects our continued efforts to invest while being efficient which contributes towards the progress on business model and operating income expansion.
As noted earlier, our goal for Q4 is to keep non-GAAP operating expenses below 230 million. Interest income and other, and interest expense is expected to net to income of approximately $3 million. Special items are expected to net to approximately 50 to $70 million. The GAAP and non-GAAP tax provision is expected to be approximately $8 million for Q3.
We expect Q3 GAAP net income per share in the range of negative $0.03 to positive $0.06 and EPS excluding special items to be in the range of $0.08 to $0.14 per share. The share count is expected to be approximately 655 million shares for both GAAP and non-GAAP shares.
In addition, we expect depreciation and software amortization of approximately $26 million and capital expenditures of approximately $15 million. Let me close by saying, we're well positioned with our customers and the markets we serve. And our focus for 2010 remains consistent.
Continued progress towards business model drive cash generation and maintain a solid balance sheet, and drive continued design win momentum for future growth. And now let me turn the call back to Abhi.

headline: LSI Corporation, Q2 2010 Earnings Call, Jul-28-2010
componenttextpreview: Thank you, Bryon. Before we go to your questions let me reinforce a few things. We are performing very well relative to the end markets we serve. Majority of our businesses are growing faster than these end markets. We've made progress against our busines
componenttext:
Thank you, Bryon. Before we go to your questions let me reinforce a few things. We are performing very well relative to the end markets we serve. Majority of our businesses are growing faster than these end markets. We've made progress against our business model this quarter, and that will remain a key focus throughout this year.
We are taking additional actions to reduce OpEx in the second half. And finally, the long-term fundamentals of our business are solid. Our design win momentum is robust, and we continue to deepen our engagements with market leading customers giving us great confidence in the future.
And let me hand the call back to Sujal.

componenttext: Good afternoon. Thanks for taking my question. I guess starting on the inventory situation. I believe you mentioned that in your SAS and SAN areas, you saw some excess inventory; you expect that to get bled down in Q3 and then grow again in Q4. Have you assessed your confidence level around that, and if you could also assess whether you see that any access inventory in the hard drive or systems supply chain, that would be very helpful.

componenttextpreview: Yes this is Abhi relative to SAN and SAS yes based on the visibility that we have had relative those inventory pockets which really contain within two to three customers. We do feel like those are have been worked through in Q2 and what's remaining will w
componenttext:
Yes this is Abhi relative to SAN and SAS yes based on the visibility that we have had relative those inventory pockets which really contain within two to three customers. We do feel like those are have been worked through in Q2 and what's remaining will work through in Q3 and just based on end market forecast and in particular server forecast in our confidence is relatively high and certainly that's factored into our forecast as well as our statement relative to how we expect Q4 to behave relative to Q3 levels.
And then in terms of inventory I think systems you ask at least at this point in time that doesn't seem to be a concern. Most of that systems business is generally configured to order, we get orders and we ship them out and there really aren't any inventory pockets throughout that supply chain.

componenttext: Thanks, that's a very helpful color. And maybe just a follow up. On the networking business you mentioned you expect a legacy decline in Q3. Can you give us a sense of the magnitude of that decline and legacy business and then whether you think how much you think there is more to go on legacy declines going forward as it goes through the next year?

componenttext: Well as we came into the year we said that we would legacy business to decline to tune of about 100 million or so and as we have been actually 50 to $70 million I am sorry and as we have been coming through this year, legacy behaved the bit better than anticipated in terms of what we see into the second half it's probably in the order of about $25 million is I think what people should expect.
